entry.title: ABAP SALV Table with Checkbox Column, Select/Deselect All, and Email Export Functionality
entry.content:
Hi all,

I have developed an ABAP report that displays employee data in a SALV table with a checkbox column. Users can select/deselect rows using custom toolbar buttons, and send the selected data as an Excel attachment via email.

The SALV table includes clickable checkboxes that toggle selection, and I handle user commands for selecting all, deselecting all, and sending email.

Please review the code below. Any suggestions on improving performance, best practices, or adding additional features would be appreciated!

Thank you!
Tcode :SE41

Create a PF Status

REPORT zsalv_factory_disply_checkbox.

" Type definition for internal table representing employee data with a checkbox
TYPES: BEGIN OF t_zemployee,
         checkbox       TYPE c LENGTH 1,                " Checkbox for selection
         employee_id    TYPE zemploye-employee_id,     " Employee ID
         company_code   TYPE zemploye-company_code,    " Company code
         bankid         TYPE zemploye-bankid,          " Bank ID
         insurance_id   TYPE zemploye-insurance_id,    " Insurance ID
         empname        TYPE zemploye-empname,         " Employee Name
         remarks        TYPE zemploye-remarks,         " Remarks
         date_of_join   TYPE zemploye-date_of_join,     " Date of Joining
         date_of_resign TYPE zemploye-date_of_resign,  " Date of Resignation
         salary         TYPE zemploye-salary,           " Salary
         currency       TYPE zemploye-currency,         " Currency
         commission     TYPE zemploye-commission,       " Commission
         currency23     TYPE zemploye-currency23,       " Additional Currency
       END OF t_zemployee.

" Global internal tables to hold employee data and selected records
DATA: gt_data  TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF t_zemployee,
      seleted  TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF t_zemployee,
      gv_repid TYPE sy-repid VALUE sy-repid.

CLASS lcl_app DEFINITION.
  PUBLIC SECTION.
    CLASS-METHODS:
      get_data,                        " Fetch data from DB into internal table
      display_data,                    " Display SALV table with checkbox
      refresh_display,                 " Refresh the SALV table display
      send_email,                     " Send selected data as email attachment
      convert_itab_to_xls_xstring     " Convert internal table to XLS XSTRING
        RETURNING VALUE(rv_xstring) TYPE xstring,
      on_link_click FOR EVENT link_click OF cl_salv_events_table
        IMPORTING row column,         " Event handler for checkbox click
      handle_user_command FOR EVENT added_function OF cl_salv_events_table
        IMPORTING e_salv_function.    " Handler for custom toolbar functions

  PRIVATE SECTION.
    CLASS-DATA: gr_table TYPE REF TO cl_salv_table.   " Reference to SALV table object
ENDCLASS.

CLASS lcl_app IMPLEMENTATION.

  " Method to fetch employee data from database and initialize checkbox field
  METHOD get_data.
    IF gt_data IS INITIAL.
      SELECT * FROM zemploye INTO CORRESPONDING FIELDS OF TABLE gt_data.
      LOOP AT gt_data ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<fs>).
        <fs>-checkbox = ''.  " Initialize checkbox as empty (unchecked)
      ENDLOOP.
    ENDIF.
  ENDMETHOD.

  " Method to display the SALV table with checkbox and event handlers
  METHOD display_data.
    lcl_app=>get_data( ).  " Load data

    IF gr_table IS INITIAL.
      TRY.
          cl_salv_table=>factory(
            IMPORTING r_salv_table = gr_table
            CHANGING  t_table      = gt_data ).
        CATCH cx_salv_msg INTO DATA(lx).
          MESSAGE lx->get_text( ) TYPE 'E'.
          RETURN.
      ENDTRY.

      " Enable all standard functions in SALV toolbar
      gr_table->get_functions( )->set_all( ).

      TRY.
          " Set custom GUI status with custom functions (PF-STATUS 'ZTOOLBAR')
          gr_table->set_screen_status(
            EXPORTING
              report        = gv_repid
              pfstatus      = 'ZTOOLBAR'
              set_functions = gr_table->c_functions_all ).
        CATCH cx_salv_msg.
      ENDTRY.

      " Set checkbox column as hotspot to allow click events
      DATA lr_columns TYPE REF TO cl_salv_columns_table.
      DATA lr_column  TYPE REF TO cl_salv_column_table.
      lr_columns = gr_table->get_columns( ).
      lr_columns->set_optimize( abap_true ).

      TRY.
          lr_column ?= lr_columns->get_column( 'CHECKBOX' ).
          lr_column->set_cell_type( if_salv_c_cell_type=>checkbox_hotspot ).
          lr_column->set_short_text( 'Select' ).
        CATCH cx_salv_not_found.
      ENDTRY.

      " Register event handlers for checkbox clicks and user commands
      DATA lo_events TYPE REF TO cl_salv_events_table.
      lo_events = gr_table->get_event( ).
      SET HANDLER lcl_app=>on_link_click FOR lo_events.
      SET HANDLER lcl_app=>handle_user_command FOR lo_events.

    ELSE.
      " Refresh SALV table if already created
      gr_table->refresh( ).
    ENDIF.

    gr_table->display( ).
  ENDMETHOD.

  " Refresh display wrapper method
  METHOD refresh_display.
    lcl_app=>display_data( ).
  ENDMETHOD.

  " Event handler to toggle checkbox on clicking checkbox cell
  METHOD on_link_click.
    FIELD-SYMBOLS: <fs> TYPE t_zemployee.
    READ TABLE gt_data ASSIGNING <fs> INDEX row.
    IF sy-subrc = 0.
      IF <fs>-checkbox = 'X'.
        <fs>-checkbox = ''.
      ELSE.
        <fs>-checkbox = 'X'.
      ENDIF.
    ENDIF.
    lcl_app=>refresh_display( ).
  ENDMETHOD.

  " Convert selected internal table data to XLS XSTRING format for attachment
  METHOD convert_itab_to_xls_xstring.
    TRY.
        cl_salv_table=>factory(
          EXPORTING
            list_display = abap_false
          IMPORTING
            r_salv_table = DATA(lo_salv_table)
          CHANGING
            t_table      = seleted ).
      CATCH cx_salv_msg INTO DATA(lx_mail).
        MESSAGE lx_mail TYPE 'E'.
    ENDTRY.

    rv_xstring = lo_salv_table->to_xml( xml_type = if_salv_bs_xml=>c_type_xlsx ).
  ENDMETHOD.

  " Send email with the selected employee data as an Excel attachment
  METHOD send_email.
    TRY.
        " Create persistent email object
        DATA(lo_mail) = cl_bcs=>create_persistent( ).

        " Sender email address
        DATA(lo_sender_address) = cl_cam_address_bcs=>create_internet_address(
                                    i_address_string = 'maniyadav2585@gmail.com' ).
        lo_mail->set_sender( lo_sender_address ).

        " Recipient email address
        DATA(recipient_address) = cl_cam_address_bcs=>create_internet_address(
                                    i_address_string = 'maniyadav2585@gmail.com' ).
        lo_mail->add_recipient( i_recipient = recipient_address ).

        " Create email document with subject and body text
        DATA(lo_document) = cl_document_bcs=>create_document(
                              i_type    = 'htm'
                              i_subject = `Excel Attachment`
                              i_text    = VALUE #( ( CONV #( 'Excel Attachment' ) ) )
                              i_sender  = lo_sender_address ).

        " Convert selected data to XLS format for attachment
        DATA(lv_excel_data) = convert_itab_to_xls_xstring( ).

        " Add the Excel attachment
        lo_document->add_attachment(
          i_attachment_type     = 'XLS'
          i_attachment_subject  = 'Employee Information'
          i_attachment_size     = xstrlen( lv_excel_data )
          i_att_content_hex     = cl_bcs_convert=>xstring_to_solix( lv_excel_data ) ).

        lo_mail->set_document( lo_document ).
        lo_mail->set_send_immediately( abap_true ).

        " Send the email
        DATA(lv_send_success) = lo_mail->send( ).
        COMMIT WORK.

      CATCH cx_send_req_bcs cx_address_bcs cx_document_bcs INTO DATA(lx_mail).
        MESSAGE lx_mail TYPE 'E'.
    ENDTRY.
  ENDMETHOD.

  " Handle custom toolbar commands (Select All, Deselect All, Send, Back)
  METHOD handle_user_command.
    FIELD-SYMBOLS: <fs> TYPE t_zemployee.
    DATA lv_count TYPE i VALUE 0.

    CASE e_salv_function.
      WHEN 'SELALL'.
        LOOP AT gt_data ASSIGNING <fs>.
          <fs>-checkbox = 'X'.
        ENDLOOP.
        lcl_app=>refresh_display( ).

      WHEN 'DESALL'.
        LOOP AT gt_data ASSIGNING <fs>.
          <fs>-checkbox = ''.
        ENDLOOP.
        lcl_app=>refresh_display( ).

      WHEN 'SEND'.
        " Collect selected records for sending
        LOOP AT gt_data ASSIGNING <fs> WHERE checkbox = 'X'.
          lv_count = lv_count + 1.
          APPEND <fs> TO seleted.
        ENDLOOP.

        IF lv_count = 0.
          MESSAGE 'Please select at least one record before sending.' TYPE 'E'.
          RETURN.
        ENDIF.

        lcl_app=>convert_itab_to_xls_xstring( ).
        lcl_app=>send_email( ).

        IF sy-subrc = 0.
          MESSAGE |{ lv_count } row(s) selected and sent.| TYPE 'S'.
        ENDIF.

      WHEN 'BACK'.
        LEAVE TO SCREEN 0.
    ENDCASE.
  ENDMETHOD.

ENDCLASS.

" Program starts here
START-OF-SELECTION.
  SET PF-STATUS 'ZTOOLBAR'.  " Set custom toolbar with your custom functions
  lcl_app=>display_data( ).

 

 

OutPut:

ABAP Connectivity

entry.title: AI Assisted Data Quality Screening in SAP Business Data Cloud
entry.content:
Ensuring Data Excellence in Mixed-Source Environments Through AI & Automated Frameworks

Introduction

Organizations today rely on data from multiple sources to drive critical business decisions in their data platform. SAP Business Data Cloud  excels at integrating both SAP and non-SAP data into a unified platform. However maintaining consistent data quality across these diverse sources presents unique challenges, especially for the non-SAP data.

SAP Business Applications typically deliver high-quality data thanks to their robust semantically rich business logic and built-in validation rules applied at the point of extraction. However, non-SAP data sources often lack these same quality safeguards, creating potential inconsistencies that can compromise analytical outcomes.

Poor data quality isn't just a technical inconvenience - it's a business risk that directly impacts your organization's ability to compete & make accurate decisions and trust the data. That’s why it should be top of mind in a data platform design to have a continuous solution.

 

What did we do?

SAP Datasphere  includes native data integrity checks, these require manual execution. But our purpose was to build something that could screen an entire environment daily & report back on the data quality inconsistencies. And we wanted it to have as little manual work to setup so we built it from the top up with AI in mind to assist

To bridge this gap, my colleagues and I have developed an advanced AI assisted Data Quality Framework (DQF) specifically engineered for SAP Datasphere environments. This framework transforms data quality management from a reactive, manual process into a proactive, automated system that continuously monitors, evaluates, and reports on data integrity across all sources.

It transforms data quality management from a time-consuming manual process into an automated system that works at the speed of your business, ensuring that every piece of data in your SAP Datasphere environment - regardless of its origin - meets the same rigorous standards you expect from native SAP business applications even when the data is not coming from SAP.

In this blog, we'll examine the key features, how this framework was built, its core capabilities, and how to use it and what results it brings. The goal is to showcase the near limitless possibilities within SAP Business Data Cloud as a modern data environment.

 

  • Key Features and Benefits

The Data Quality Framework (DQF) is meticulously designed to ensure the integrity and accuracy of data within SAP Datasphere, especially of non-SAP data & manual data like excel, csv, etc. The framework performs a series of critical checks, including the identification of NULL values in key fields, referential integrity checks with master data, and duplicate records detection. These checks provide accurate record-level details necessary for data validation, cleansing, governance, and monitoring and reporting.

At the end the results of the checks are posted to a report which can be used by IT or business to fix the data quality & integrity issues in the files or systems.

 

  • Use Cases and Prerequisites

The Data Quality Framework is versatile and can validate data from various sources, including non-SAP sources like Databases, CSV files, excel files, etc. It can also be used to do checks on data created within  SAP Datasphere after using joins.

The setup requires access to the SAP HANA Cloud Database in SAP Datasphere & setup of a user, couple of tables & Stored procedures in that HANA Layer. Additionally, any views the stored procedure needs to screen should be exposed for consumption.

 

  • Architecture

The architecture of our DQF is designed to handle screenings efficiently & automatically and showcase the errors to end users to take action on the Data Quality itself.

The process begins with the main procedure: the ETL_RunScreenings. This script starts the process with a couple of parameters to allow customisability: Only check object x, only check objects in space y, only execute check 1.

The orchestra master if you will is a list called Screenings. This is an AI generated table that consists all of the screening rules per data object in your data platform. See an example below. We gave an agent the structure of the table, the functional blueprint of the DQF, code & ERD schema’s of our Data Warehouse Billing Model. The question was then asked: Populate this table to the best of your ability. The result:

Following this, the Framework then branches into three critical checks: ETL_SCREEN_REFERENTIAL_INTEGRITY, ETL_SCREEN_DUPLICATE, and ETL_SCREEN_NULLKEYS. Each of these checks points to respective error tables, ensuring that any discrepancies are promptly identified and addressed. The framework allows for multiple ETL Screening but currently there are 3:

  • Referential Integrity check: Checks if the key value in a fact finds a key value in the dimension. This ensures an association will retrieve master data.
  • Duplicate Check: Checks if a duplicate exists on a certain key
  • Null Keys/mal keys Check: Checks if one of the fields that is set as key has null values

 

  • Implementation Steps

Implementing the DQF involves several key steps:

  1. Create a database user in the Datasphere tenant. (Use Space Management)
  2. Create tables and stored procedures in the open SQL schema of the created database user. (Code will shared later once quality reviewed – we used DBeaver for this)
  3. Grant access to the Datasphere space for the task chain to access the stored procedures.
  4. Create task chains to schedule the stored procedure runs.
  5. Feed an AI Agent or LLM of choice with the code, table layout of SCREENING & ERD schema of your model and ask to fill in the rules. Do a visual check afterward & manually adjust where needed.
  6. Create a view to combine the screening tables.
  7. Report errors using a report built in SAP Analytics Cloud 

 

  • End Result

To illustrate the practical application of the DQF, let’s look at example diagram of the data flow in a DSP system. The diagram highlights the flow of data from source entities through transformations and unions, leading to storage and further processing. Key elements include entities, dimensions, facts, attributes, and a screening framework, with specific keys and NULL replacements noted.

The result is an error page on which you can build a report. See example below where it shows what constraint was violated in what screening run & what the values were that caused the error. See for example line 7 where a duplicate key was found & then it shows the exact key that created the duplicate.

A business or IT user can then take matters into control & fix the data at source based on this report. Or coordinate if action/logic needs to be developed in the Data Platform to catch this.

 

Conclusion

In conclusion: the Data Quality Framework we created is an AI-driven automated solution to enhance data integrity and accuracy within SAP Datasphere & SAP Business Data Cloud on a constant basis. It builds on top of the already powerful manual integrity checks. But the framework expands by offering a daily, automated & AI assisted approach. By implementing these kind of checks consistently, organizations can ensure that their data is reliable, consistent, and ready for informed decision-making.

What’s next? We are looking to expand to do data type check. We are now also running full validation on the script & doing some code quality & clean-up. Once this is done, we can share the script. Feel free to contact me at simon.vandelanotte@delaware.pro if you want a sneak peak.

Because fun fact: The script was partly written thanks to assistance from AI. As neither Premalatha or myself are SQLscript coders from background, this was our first experience!

I hope this case already inspires on the endless possibilities with SAP Business Data Cloud& inspire around the important topic of Data Quality and how proactively being on top of this is critical to the success of a modern data platform. And lastly how AI doesn’t replace the process but can enhance it & save time.

Big thanks to my colleague Premalatha Kamaraj for writing this script & Gilles De Rore for the idea!

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Table Maintenance Reimagined: Choosing the Right Framework
entry.content:
In this blog, we’ll explore a practical use case implemented in S/4HANA 2021 On-Premise, where we opted for Custom Business Objects (CBO) to enable table maintenance via Fiori with minimal development effort and also evaluate new frameworks to achieve this in latest S4/HANA release 2023.

Approach for choosing Custom Business Object (Decision Matrix)

CBO is based on BOPF framework which was widely used by SAP before the era of RAP (RESTful ABAP Programming), while this is still relevant, SAP has now moved to RAP based development and a new concept called custom business configuration, both will be covered later in context of data maintenance.

Why we didn’t choose RAP or Custom business configuration for this use case.
  1. Custom business configuration ( Business configuration maintenance object ) – This is available from S4 On-Prem 2022 onwards and the Fiori app for CUBCO is available after 2023 onwards.
  2. RESTful ABAP Programming – SAP has provided RAP Generator which can generate all the artefacts based on a table right from views, behavior definition , service binding , generation to Fiori app however this is also not available in On-Prem 2021, the other workaround could be to build all these artefacts manually and generate Fiori app which was going to take more development time, hence it was avoided.

Since we cannot go with above 2 options, the only 2 options left are SM30 and Custom Business object, as we want to move towards Fiori first approach, Custom business object was chosen as the Go to approach. Let us deep dive in this with the help of use- case and practical tips

What is Custom Business Object –

With the Custom Business Objects Fiori app, you can create and manage custom business objects. A custom business object is a hierarchical set of database tables with an API for creation, retrieval, update and deletion of data.

  • In The Fiori App ‘Custom Business Object’, a new BO has been defined and maintained as below.
  • User can choose what options do they want as part of framework, e,g, Change document, system admin date (last change at, created at etc are added by default).
  • User interface is disabled in this since it is only possible to enable if Embedded gateway is used which is not the case here.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

You are free to choose what kind of operations, out of CUD, should be supported in the BO out of box.

This is where all the fields are defined for BO.

Final Output –

Until this point, no coding has been done except for few changes in CDS Metadata for Fiori UI related cosmetic changes, all the operation are handled by framework out of box.

An additional button ‘Mass upload’ was added in metadata extension which is using intent-based navigation to navigate to another GUI application for mass upload of the entries.

 

Few Tips -
  1. Custom Table (Type Application) is auto generated in this case with Key field as UUID.
  2. Data entries maintained in one system cannot be transported to other system and must be maintained in target system, which was also the requirement in our use case.
  3. Once business object is published and moved to production, Deletion is not allowed.

How does the future look like for the same activity (Table Maintenance)-

As discussed above, there are 2 other ways to achieve this with minimal development efforts in new S4 HANA releases.

  1. Custom Business Configuration

    This is recommended approach going forward where a business configuration maintenance object serves as primary entry point for maintenance.
  • We have the option to use the Generate ABAP Repository Objects Wizard for Business configuration maintenance object to generate all required development objects based on a customizing table
  • Based on the Business configuration maintenance object, the custom business configurations app renders a Fiori element list report for the entities exposed by the service binding to maintain the configuration entries

Image courtesy - SAP

In short, Custom business configuration (Fiori app) is an umbrella under which all maintenance objects will be listed and serves as one stop shop while maintenance objects are the actual ABAP artefact which contains all the definition related to Object maintenance.

  • Different options like SM30 are available by default such Add copy action out of box.
  • Add Data Consistency Check for fields with fixed domain values or foreign key screen check.

All of the below objects are created by default including CDS view, service definition, service binding, business object maintenance , transport definition, implementation classes etc.

Few Practical Tips –
  • All tables must have a client key field and delivery class C
  • Have a timestamp field with data element ABP_LASTCHANGE_TSTMPL
  • To enable the "No Transport" option in the ADT wizard, implement SAP Note  https://me.sap.com/notes/3579012.
  • With few tweaks, it is possible to maintain data directly in production system instead of transporting. More details in this blog

As of version SAP S/4HANA release 2022, customers can use the generator for Business Configuration objects. The Custom Business Configurations SAP Fiori app is not yet available; app has been made available in release 2023.

 

2. RAP Generator 

Second approach to achieve this is using same generation wizard from context menu of table.

How is Custom business configuration different than plain RAP generator?
  • Custom business configuration is a framework which is also built on RAP artefacts, but it has other framework related functionalities (e.g change log for auditing) in comparison to plain RAP application.
  • Fiori for CBC can be accessed through generic custom business configuration app serving as single source of entry whereas RAP application should be exposed as standalone app.
  • Custom business configuration app is built only around customizing tables whereas RAP generator can be built around any customizing and application tables both.
  • CBC provides in built functionality to capture entries into transport request, but RAP generator requires explicit changes to incorporate transport feature.
How is Custom business configuration different than custom business object?
  • Custom business configuration is built on RAP framework (SAP recommended) whereas custom business objects is built on BOPF framework.
  • Custom business configuration has transport feature for data entries whereas custom business object does not any way to transport entries from one system to other system.
  • Custom business configuration is bottom-up approach where custom tables are defined first, and rest of the artifacts are generated around that whereas custom business object works on top-down approach where business object is created first then custom table is generated around BO.
  • Custom business configuration supports only OData V4 where CBO supports OData V2.
  • Custom business configuration app is built only around customizing tables whereas custom business object is built around application tables.
  • Once CBO has moved to production, it cannot be deleted.
  • In both the case, Metadata can be enhanced for any Fiori related UI changes, also additional validation, actions are supported in both.

Additional reading-

  • https://help.sap.com/docs/ABAP_PLATFORM_NEW/b5670aaaa2364a29935f40b16499972d/047e01c3bcdd4303a60b61364bd5b31d.html?locale=en-US&version=202310.002
  • https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/custom-business-configuration/ba-p/13647767

entry.title: Step-by-Step Guide to Creating a SOAP API in SAP S/4HANA and Configuring It Using SOAMANAGER
entry.content:
Hi Everyone,
In this blog post, I will walk you through the process of creating a SOAP-based web service in SAP S/4HANA, and demonstrate how to configure and expose it using SOAMANAGER for consumption by external systems.

What is SOAP API ?

SOAP API stands for Simple Object Access Protocol.

It is a protocol-based method of communication that allows different systems to exchange data over a network — usually using XML messages over HTTP or HTTPS.

Difference Between SOAP API and Rest API

Feature / Aspect          SOAP API (in SAP)                                    REST API (in SAP)

TechnologyWeb Service (Enterprise Service, Function Module via SOAMANAGER)OData service via SAP Gateway (or RAP in S/4HANA)
Tool UsedSPROXY,SOAMANAGER, SE37SAP Gateway, SEGW, CDS Views, RAP Model.
Data FormatXML onlyMostly JSON (also supports XML)
Typical Use CaseIntegration with legacy systems, middleware, PI/POFiori apps, mobile apps, third-party REST integrations
SecurityWS-Security, SAML, SSLHTTPS, OAuth 2.0, SAML
PerformanceHeavier (due to XML parsing and SOAP envelope)Faster and lighter (especially with JSON)
Contract DescriptionWSDL file.$metadata (EDMX format) via OData.
Preferred InECC or S/4 for BAPIs, ALE, PI/PO scenarios.S/4HANA, Fiori Elements, RESTful integrations.


Step 1:Create a Structure & Table Type for Request and Response.

Objects with the naming convention ZCH* are designed to be transported across all systems (DEV → QA → PROD).

In contrast, objects with the naming convention YCH* are typically created only for development purposes and are stored in the $TMP package, meaning they are local objects and will not be transported. These may be deleted later.

YCH_CUST_REQ is the request structure.



We need to save in $TMP.

YCH_CUST_REQ_TT is the table type which is consuming YCH_CUST_REQ structure

We are storing the request table type in $TMP

YCH_CUST_RES_S is the Response Payload and stored in the $tmp package




Table type YCH_CUST_RES_TT is the table type & it is consuming YCH_CUST_RES_S and stored in $TMP package.

 

Step2) Creating RFC FM and saved in $TMP Package

So here we are declaring IM_REQUEST as Import parameter with type of Table Type of Request (YCH_CUST_REQ_TT)


So here we are declaring EX_RESPONSE as Export parameter with type of Table Type of Request (YCH_CUST_RES_TT)

There will be no logic written inside the function module only Importing and exporting parameter will be defined

Step 3)Creation of Web service

We need to go for Utilities ->More Utilities->Create web service->From the function Module.

Provide the service definition name and Description

By Default it will take Function module name

By Default it will assign SOAP Appl & Profile


Click on local object check box so that by default it will be assigned to $TMP package

Click on finish to create web service

What is WSDL ?
It is an XML-based language used to describe web services and how to access them. Think of it as a contract between the service provider and the consumer, detailing what the service does, where it can be accessed, and how to interact with it.

Once after that go to WSDL tab and Click on export symbol and download the data in Notepad

So in the WSDL file change the filed type from "tns:char10" to "xsd: String" as below in the downloaded Notepad from WSDL tab.

 


Step 4) Go to Sproxy tcode

Click on New icon to create Service Consumer.

Select the service Consumer radio button


Select External/WSDL schema.

Chose local file

Choose the local file path for the WSDL.

Provide the package with workbench task request & provide the prefix so that we will taken as reference to create a SOAP class.

click on finish

Save the Service Consumer YSRV_SRV_DEF


Change the Release status from Not Released to Released state and Activate the Service Consumer.

So in the External View Tab we can see all Request and Response Fields.



Soap Class ZCH_CL_CO_YSRV_SRV_DEF will be generated automatically which is helpful in sending and receiving the data using the method YCUST_SOAP_API



Step 5) Execute SOAMANAGER Tcode.

An web page will be opened 

Select Web service Configuration

Search our proxy(YSRV_SRV_DEF) in Object type as showed below

We will get the SOAP Class click on that & go for Create -> Manual Configuration

Provide the Logical Port name & description. Click on next

So in Consumer Security Provide the User Id & Password that will be Provided from CPI team (Middleware/Integration Team).

Assign the Endpoint URL which will be Provided from CPI team (Middleware/Integration Team). which will be linked to CPI system.

Change the Message ID protocol to Suppress ID transfer and click on finish.

Once after finishing the soamanger configuration click on the below highlighted icon for Ping the web service.

By pinging the SOAMANGER web service we can Validate our Endpoint, Username & Password.

If it's Successful then we will get the result as below else we will get error.



Step 6)Create a report program that consumes a SOAP API to send and receive data.

REPORT zcv_r_soap_api.
DATA:ls_req TYPE zch_cl_soap_ycust_soap_api,   
     ls_res TYPE  zch_cl_soap_ycust_soap_apiresp.

SELECT FROM kna1 FIELDS kunnr,name1 INTO TABLE (gt_cust).

LOOP AT gt_cust INTO DATA(ls_cust).
  APPEND VALUE zch_cl_ych_cust_req( customer = ls_cust-kunnr name = ls_cust-name1 ) TO ls_req-im_request-item.
ENDLOOP.

DATA(go_ref)  = NEW zch_cl_co_ysrv_srv_def( ).
TRY.
    go_ref->ycust_soap_api(
      EXPORTING
        input  = ls_req
      IMPORTING
        output = ls_res
    ).
  CATCH cx_ai_system_fault INTO DATA(ls_error). " Communication Error
    MESSAGE ls_error->get_text( ) TYPE 'E'.
    ENDTRY.

In the  above report program, ZCH_CL_SOAP_YCUST_SOAP_API and ZCH_CL_SOAP_YCUST_SOAP_APIRESP are automatically generated structures from the proxy class ZCH_CL_CO_YSRV_SRV_DEF, and are defined as the exporting and importing parameters, respectively, for the method YCUST_SOAP_API.

In the report, I am using the statement APPEND VALUE ZCH_CL_YCH_CUST_REQ at line 8. Here, ZCH_CL_YCH_CUST_REQ is a deep structure that is part of the structure ZCH_CL_SOAP_YCUST_SOAP_API, which was generated by the proxy class.

Later, we created an object of the class ZCH_CL_CO_YSRV_SRV_DEF, through which we called the method YCUST_SOAP_API. The request data is passed in the structure ls_req, and the response is received in the structure ls_res.

Any errors related to the proxy call will be handled in the CATCH block using ABAP's TRY...CATCH exception handling mechanism.

entry.title: AI-Driven Engineering Research and Development (ER&D) @Nasscom Design & Engineering Summit 2025
entry.content:
I recently had the privilege of attending the Nasscom Design & Engineering Summit 2025. Through a series of thoughtfully curated sessions, I gained valuable insights into how cutting-edge AI technologies are reshaping the landscape of engineering research and development. These advancements are empowering industries to design smarter, more resilient systems that can adapt and thrive in a rapidly evolving future. Here are some of my key learnings from this transformative event, specifically on AI-driven Engineering Research &Development:

1. AI as an Innovation Accelerator and Strategic Imperative

AI has rapidly evolved from being a niche technology into becoming the heartbeat of Engineering Research and Development (ER&D), fundamentally reshaping how organizations innovate, compete, and deliver value. An AI-first approach is no longer optional, it is a strategic necessity for organizations to thrive amid today’s geopolitical fluctuations, supply chain uncertainties, and ever-changing market expectations. This involves focusing on the following key shifts and opportunities:

  • Catalyzing Rapid Innovation Cycles:  AI is dramatically compressing the time from proof-of-concept to market-ready product. What once took 7 years can now be achieved in as little as 2, thanks to advanced simulation technologies, which allow engineers to identify and correct design flaws early, thereby reducing costly iterations.
  • AI-Enabled Design Co-Piloting:  The role of engineers is being redefined as they increasingly collaborate with AI tools, not just as AI assistants, but as true co-creators.
  • Strategic Necessity, Not Optional Efficiency: Embracing AI is not merely about incremental efficiency gains; it is about closing the innovation gap with global peers. Organizations that fail to pivot to an AI-first mindsetrisk being left behind in a rapidly evolving landscape.
  • Rise of IP and Virtual Companions: The convergence of the experience economy and the Gen economy is creating a new value equation. This shift moves enterprises from being process-driven to 'generative-driven' and from asset-based to IP-based.
  • Building India’s Innovation Edge: With a $55.7 billion revenue, the third-largest talent pool globally, and a growing ecosystem of Global Capability Centers (GCCs), India is transitioning from an execution hub to a global innovation partner.

Key Takeaway: AI has become the strategic engine powering faster innovation, redefining engineering roles, accelerating product development cycles, and opening new IP-driven opportunities, making an AI- first approach essential for organizations seeking to lead in today’s dynamic global landscape.

2. The Evolving Landscape of AI-Enabled, Software-Defined Products

The traditional product lifecycle based on fixed hardware designs and static functionality, is being fundamentally reimagined through AI-powered Software-Defined Everything (SDx). In this new era, products are no longer stagnant; they have become dynamic ecosystems that continuously adapt and improve long after deployment. The shift to SDx creates new opportunities, such as:

  • AI-driven feedback mechanisms that allow products to self-correct and improve performance.
  • Predictive maintenance models that reduce downtime and prevent failures.
  • Standardized manufacturing platforms, such as software-defined factories, where robots and machines can learn new tasks through software, accelerating both flexibility and scalability.

Key Takeaway: AI-powered, software-defined products are transforming static devices into continuously evolving ecosystems that adapt, self-improve, and unlock unprecedented flexibility across industries.

3. Responsible and Secure AI Engineering

AI introduces new vulnerabilities and attack surfaces that require a fresh approach to security and reliability. The central question now is not whether we can use AI, but whether we could use AI responsibly.

AI-Specific Threats: Beyond Traditional Attacks

The rapid evolution of AI systems has created unprecedented security concerns that must be addressed:

  • Prompt Injection Attacks: Malicious prompts can be inserted into seemingly benign user inputs, causing a large language model (LLM)-powered workflow to download and execute ransomware payloads. Prompt injection leverages a model’s tendency to follow instructions, even when hidden within data.
  • Model Inversion & Data Leakage: Attackers can query the model with carefully crafted inputs and analyze its outputs to reverse-engineer the original sensitive data.
  • Supply Chain Attacks: These occur when adversaries target any stage of the model development or deployment pipeline, not just the model itself. Such attacks exploit trust relationships and dependencies between models, datasets, third-party libraries, and deployment environments.
  • Adversarial Manipulation: This technique exploits vulnerabilities in AI models, often to alter predictions or outputs without detection, undermining the reliability and trustworthiness of AI-driven systems.

For a comprehensive view, practitioners should consult frameworks like MITRE ATLAS, for cataloguing and benchmarking known AI attack patterns.

Human Accountability and Fallback Mechanisms

AI should be given only restricted autonomy in decision-making, with essential human oversight and accountability maintained at all times. Human-in-the-loop processes remain essential due to oversight of AI where Humans are essential for catching hallucinations (plausible but false information), erroneous recommendations, or unexpected behavior. A dual-model approach using a second LLM to validate the first's output has proven eﬀective for managing hallucinations. Fallback Processes with predefined escalation routes ensure that if AI fails or is attacked, human experts can intervene quickly to remediate risk and maintain trust.

Human-Centric, Ethical AI

A human-centric, ethical approach dictates that artificial intelligence must serve humanity in a fair, trustworthy, and transparent manner, enriching both society and the environment. This demands a shift from purely technical performance to systems co-created with purpose, values, and responsibility at their core.

As first-generation engineers witnessing the evolution of AI as it becomes not just a tool but a teammate, the next revolution will be "conscious design", shifting from machines that think to systems that are designed with ethical awareness in mind. Trust, transparency, and responsibility will become paramount as context-aware, anticipatory systems become the norm. With Agentic AI, spatial computing, and emotional AI driving the next wave, engineers must build ecosystems that are intelligent and human-centered.

Key Takeaway: AI's power demands not just innovation but responsible engineering and vigilant human oversight and accountability to ensure security, trust, and ethical alignment at every step.

4. Report Launch: Engineering Intelligence GenAI’s Disruption and India’s Strategic Advantage

Published by NASSCOM and ISG (Information Services Group), this report explores how generative AI is set to transform Engineering R&D, highlighting high-impact use cases across product innovation, manufacturing, and research. It also showcases India’s potential to become a global hub for GenAI-powered engineering excellence.

🔗 Read the full report here.

5. Talent Imperatives for AI Success

Organizations are currently at the edge of an AI revolution, with their tech ecosystem poised to capitalize on transformative advances. However, realizing AI’s full potential depends on foundational shifts in talent, culture, and collaboration:

  • Bridging the Innovation Gap and Fostering Talent Fluency: Significant skills gaps remain in deep tech and AI. To bridge these gaps, accelerated upskilling, dynamic cross-sector partnerships, and ingraining AI fluency across engineering disciplines are crucial. Creating patents that solve real customer problems and measuring the impact of innovation is essential.
  • Strengthening Industry-Academia Synergy: A blend of formal education and industry experience is critical to bridging the gap between academia and industry. Engineers need the expertise to know when and how to use GenAI, and it should be an integral part of education rather than an add-on topic.
  • Instilling a Culture of Experimentation and Leadership-Driven Innovation: To unlock AI's full value, organizations need a culture rooted in curiosity, rapid learning cycles, and the willingness to take calculated risks. Leaders must champion an innovation mindset, embedding AI as core to their organizational DNA while encouraging experimentation, iterative improvement, and a continuous pursuit of excellence.

Key Takeaway:

Driving AI success in Organizations demands bridging skill gaps with targeted upskilling, forging stronger industry-academia ties, and cultivating a culture of curiosity-led, leadership-driven innovation.  

My sincere thanks to the entire Nasscom team and all the speakers for meticulously curating this event and sharing such thought-provoking insights.

A special thank you to Sindhu Gangadharan, Milesh Jamburao, and Siva Kumar Vemula for giving me this wonderful opportunity through SAP Labs India. 

Disclaimer : The views expressed in this article are those of mine as an individual

entry.title: Re: Crystal Reports 2008: Cannot use linked parameter for...
entry.content:
You cannot pass a data set as a parameter. Each linked parameter would pass the field value from a SINGLE record in the main report to the subreport.

Consider one of the following solutions:

  1. Insert CrossTabs with different designs to achieve different sorting & grouping (no subreports needed).
  2. Use parameters to control sorting and grouping of the main report (no subreports needed). Requires interactive use in Preview. Since the parameters are not involved in record selection, changing them does NOT require data refresh.
  3. Like 2, but automate exporting to PDF using different sort/group parameters, followed by merging of the pdf files to a single document (for non-interactive use). 
  4. Materialize the result set on SQL Server (to a table) and reuse it across subreports.

entry.title: Re: APM - Paying current BrokerVendor regardless of trans...
entry.content:
Hi,

Thanks for your question!

We see this situation due to mergers /agency buyouts and is somewhat of a complicated scenario due to APMs ability to retroactively process payments. During retroactive processing, APM checks to see if the same agent and agency are the same as what was previously paid, if not, a full chargeback is done and the new agent/agency is paid. If the current calendar date is used to look up payee, this can create chargebacks to agencies that are no longer with the carrier.  There are a lot of requirements that would need to be flushed out before any design could be started. More than likely, this change would not be a simple option change but would require thoughtful analysis and significant testing to ensure desired behavior. Any design would also handle previous paid transactions with the intended outcomes. I have worked with SAP Services and our partners to implement this type of configuration so i know it can be done! Feel free to reach out directly for more details.

Phillip

phillip.butts@sap.com

entry.title: Understanding Bundles and Scenarios in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
Introduction

When starting an implementation in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, one of the first setup steps is defining the scope. Two important concepts in this process are bundles and scenarios. These determine which business processes are available in your system.

What is a Bundle?

A bundle is a predefined collection of business scenarios grouped by a specific business focus.

  • Bundles simplify the scoping process by offering ready-made sets of scenarios.

  • They are country/region-specific, meaning their content may differ depending on the selected country or region.

Available Bundles

  • Baseline Accelerator
    ▪ The essential bundle containing the minimum set of finance-related processes required for a functioning system.

  • Enterprise Management
    ▪ A comprehensive bundle for large enterprises.
    ▪ Includes all content of the Baseline Accelerator plus additional processes such as sales, procurement, and manufacturing.

  • Retail
    ▪ Industry-specific bundle for retail.
    ▪ License-dependent.

  • Public Sector Management
    ▪ Focused on managing budgets, revenue, and expenditure for public institutions.
    ▪ Relevant for government, nonprofit, and educational organizations.
    ▪ Cannot be selected together with other bundles.

Note: The Finance-Led and Professional Services bundles are deprecated and remain available only for customers who had selected them earlier.

Requirement: At least one bundle must be selected in the system scope.

What is a Scenario?

A scenario represents predefined content to support a specific business process.

  • Example: Time Recording (1Q4)

  • Each scenario is identified by a unique three-digit ID, making it easy to locate in the system.

  • Scenarios provide flexibility to tailor the system to the exact processes required by the business.

Group Ledger Scenarios

When defining scope for the first time, a group ledger scenario must be chosen. This choice determines how financial reporting and statements are handled.

Two options are available:

  • Accounting and Financial Close – Group Ledger US GAAP (2VA)

  • Accounting and Financial Close – Group Ledger IFRS (1GA)

Caution: This selection is irreversible. Once finalized, group ledger scenarios cannot be added, removed, or changed later.

License-Dependent and Non-Standard Scenarios

Not all scenarios are included by default:

  • License-dependent scenarios
    ▪ Marked with a lock icon.
    ▪ Require a support case to activate (component: XX-S4C-OPR-SRV).

  • Non-standard scenarios
    ▪ Marked with a warning icon.
    ▪ Trigger a warning message before being added.
    ▪ If confirmed, the change is logged.

Key Points to Remember

  • Bundles = predefined sets of scenarios (mandatory to select at least one).

  • Scenarios = individual business processes (flexible selection).

  • Group ledger scenario = critical one-time decision (US GAAP or IFRS).

  • Some scenarios require additional licenses or approvals.

By understanding bundles and scenarios, you can scope their SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition solution more efficiently and align the system with their business requirements from the start.

entry.title: Re: How do I create a dataflow to reset passwords and not...
entry.content:
Hi Team,

 

You can use endpoint "accounts.setAccountInfo". You need to pass parameter "requirePasswordChange": When this property is passed, the only valid value is TRUE and once set, it is immutable and will force the user to change their password on the next login.

This can be done via a Dataflow in case you already know the affected users.

 

Best Regards,

SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Data Mismatch Issue in SAC Story after Import from Fi...
entry.content:
Hello @Preeti_G1 

unfortunately it is not 100% clear to me if you compare SAC Story live data with your Datasphere data or if you uploaded the same also into another SAC model.

However... you should first check your key settings in your DSP data target table and list some records there in the preview, to make sure you can find the same values like available in your flat files. I think it is most likely that your keys don't match and that you overwrite some data.

Otherwise, if the result is fine there, then compare the data in the Analytic Model preview vs. your import table.

Finally it might be you had set some background filters in your SAC story...  so you should maybe compare the data with the SAC Analyzer first to see it this is still matching or not.

BR, Martin

entry.title: Re: Hi Folks - Anyone using automation to setup bulk volu...
entry.content:
Hello @AnshulJ 

For  SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, classic BAPIs like BAPI_COMPANYCODE_CREATE1 or BAPI_FLCU_CREATE/CHANGE are not available in ABAP Cloud and cannot be used; company codes must be created in Central Business Configuration (CBC), and customer/financial data through released OData APIs (e.g., API_BUSINESS_PARTNER).

Refer to the useful SAP Documentation

  • CBC – Organisational Structure
  • ABAP Cloud – Use Only Released APIs
  • API Hub – Business Partner API

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Availability in S/4HANA public cloud about KBA 335192...
entry.content:
Hello @Mika_Suzumoto 

Thank you for the update. I have looked into your points.

Consult Custom Business Objects, Fields, and Logic & Country/Region-Specific Functions - Overview

However, to summarise, there is an important distinction between S4 on-premise and S4 public cloud that needs to be put into consideration.

On-premise

Public Cloud 

·         Country specific screen/enhancement like vendor are delivered in the Financial Services BP Extension.

·         You can activate them directly.

·         The Business Partner master data UI is simplified and only exposes released country specific fields.

·         Valid period for Tax registration for Japan is one of functions that are note delivered to Public Cloud.

 

The options you have to work around the limitations are:

  • To make use of custom field and logic app to store the valid period for Tax registration. Then enable it for supplier Master Data UIs and to replicate it to APIs. This ensures it flows through the MDS into the public cloud.
  • Since you are replicating from MDG, you have the option to map the on-premise country specific field into a custom field in public cloud.

Else, raise an incident on the affected component or submit this to the customer influence portal.

Best regards

Chris
